Part X | Market models are flexible

In Part A we set up the landscape of what's possible. But we left with the question where on the PPF is best. In Part B we introduced markets as a way to arbitrate which point on the PPF we should choose. And we showed that competitive markets without externalities deliver a quantity that maximizes Total Surplus. In Part C we introduced the concept of Market Failure, when markets deliver a quantity that society does not want. We then introduced a type of government policy to correct this failure. Then as we saw in Part D, markets aren't always the right tool.

In Part E and Part F, we're returning to markets for private goods, building up models of buyers and sellers in more detail.

Part X is a bit of an interlude, bringing together many tools in market models into one project, showing some interesting applications of markets before diving back into the theory of buyers and sellers. We're discussing the simplest of models of international trade and government purchases.

Take a look at an animated video of international trade I put together for my students during the early days of COVID. The labeling is different than we're using this semester but the content is identical.

Reading | Ch. 9

Start Part X by skimming the reading to develop an understanding of the scope of what's being discussed.

Then once you've finished reading, take a look at the practice material, and use the text as a resource when you need help. This way, you know what's most important, get to practicing quickly, and know where to find help when you innevitably get stuck.

Vignette X

Vignette X is a novel scenario we examine as a class.

Demo Xs

Demo Xs are very similar to the type of problems you'll see on MiniExam X. There are three versions, taken from past semesters. These are resources for you to use as you'd like. But here's my advice. Start by trying to solve them on your own. Or even better, grab a classmate and find a whiteboard in the library. Then once you've worked through enough to give yourself some confidence, use the video and solutions to check your work. You're more than welcome to watch this video first, but you're not going to catch your weak points as easily, which is the main point.

Demo X1 Solutions

Demo X1 was given as a homework question in a past semester, examining international trade.

Demo X2 Solutions

Demo X2 examines a clever government policy employed in the US after WWII.

Demo X3 Solutions

Demo X3 is adaped from Demo X1, exploring a different policy in a similar context.

MiniExam X

MiniExam X will be held on March 16 and covers everything in Part X, primarily international trade and government purchases. If you understand the concepts and do the work in the Vignettes and Demos, you're going to be in good shape on the MiniExam.
